definition:
An integer $n > 0$ is called a [*noncototient*]{} if there is no
solution to $x - {\phi}(x) = n$, where ${\phi}(x)$ is Euler’s totient
function. The first few noncototients are 10, 26, 34, 50, 52, 58, 86,
100, 116, 122, 130 (listed in A005278 of Sloane’s OEIS).

Browkin and Schinzel proved in 1995 that there are infinitely many
noncototients. What is still unknown is whether they are all even.
Goldbach’s conjecture would seem to suggest that this is the case: given
a semiprime $pq$, it follows that
$pq - {\phi}(pq) = pq - (p - 1)(q - 1) = p + q - 1$, an odd number if
$2 < p \le q$.
